data.title: Figure: A Buy As Loan Types Increase
data.description:
Everywhere you look in today's stock market, it's difficult to escape the pessimism that has infected growth stocks, recent IPOs, the crypto market, and software industry. Figure Technology Solutions (FIGR), which went public last September at $25 per share, touches all of those themes: and needless to say it has crashed spectacularly over the past few months, as companies continue to view this blockchain pioneer as a crypto-adjacent name.

Since the start of January alone, shares of Figure have lost ~20% of their value. Relative to peaks near $75 briefly notched in January, Figure is down more than 50%. The company's recent strong Q4 earnings print did little to quell the bearish frenzy. We have to ask ourselves now: at what point does the selloff become overdone?

I last wrote a buy article on Figure in the $70s. I've maintained that bullish outlook since the company's IPO. Even though I acknowledge that my January buy call was ill-timed (I certainly wasn't predicting the sharp selloff in tech that would ensue), my thesis on Figure remains sound. I view the company as an incredibly differentiated innovator in the blockchain that is poised to displace and take market share from incumbent lenders: not just in mortgage originations, but now in auto financing as well. I reiterate my buy rating here.

Figure's immense growth within its existing consumer loan marketplace is astounding (more detail in the next section), but what investors should be aware of today is the fact that the company is planning a broad extension of its platform in 2026. Figure built its platform and its name brand around one type of loan, the HELOC (home equity line of credit). But in itself, HELOC loans are relatively niche product that form a very small share of overall borrowing.

In 2026, the company is focused on expanding two loan types. The first is primary, first-lien mortgages. Already, the company is showcasing tremendous growth in first lien, with volumes rising roughly 3x y/y in the fourth quarter to $506 million. Still, first lien (standard mortgages) represents only 19% of the company's origination volume. Figure's management also notes that it typically is able to issue a standard mortgage with a total cost of under $1,000 (thanks to automating many manual portions of the underwriting process, and with higher credit accuracy) versus an industry average of $11,045, marking a clear advantage for lenders.

The next expansion area is completely beyond housing. Figure has struck a partnership with a company called Agora Data, which describes itself as an AI-powered intelligence platform for auto loan originators to predict performance of subprime auto loans and to connect lenders to capital.

Agora gives Figure easy access to its base of auto lenders, marking its first foray into an auto lending TAM that is sized at a staggering $1.6 trillion. While Agora's platform is responsible for origination in this deal (which is Figure's role in home loans), Figure's role is to use its newly-launched Figure Connect to tokenize these loans into assets on the blockchain: which makes it easier and less costly for auto loan originators to securitize and sell their loans using the Figure platform. In my view, it's an excellent expansion of Figure's use cases, and a great utilization of Figure Connect.

In short, with so many tailwinds ahead for Figure in 2026, there is little reason for this stock to crash post-earnings. Take advantage of the dip as a buying opportunity.

Q4 Download

Let's now go through Figure's latest quarterly results in greater detail. The Q4 earnings summary is shown below:

Figure's revenue grew 91% y/y to $159.9 million, beating Wall Street's expectations of $157.7 million (+88% y/y) by three-point margin. Important to note is the fact that Figure's revenue accelerated sharply from just 55% y/y growth in Q3. Similar to the prior quarter, Figure's y/y surge in revenue was driven primarily by Figure Exchange, the company's crypto trading platform which launched in midway through 2024 (revenue recorded in the "ecosystem and technology fees" line. Still, we note that crypto trading is only one-quarter of the company's overall revenue (despite now having negative associations with the crypto sector that has brought down Figure's stock tremendously).

Core lines of business, meanwhile, also thrived. The chart below showcases the company's main business driver: the amount of loans originated through the company's platform. Consumer loan marketplace volume surged 131% y/y to $2.71 billion in Q4, which accelerated versus just 63% full-year growth across the entirety of FY25.

Again, it's the expansion of loan types that is potentially feeding growth acceleration here, as the company focuses more on first-lien originations (which not only is a larger market than home equity lines, but also tend to have higher loan balances). The company's 2026 foray into auto loans should only serve to add fuel to recent growth trends. We note as well that Figure's take rates (its revenue as a percentage of origination volume) jumped 30bps y/y to 3.8%, which is a major tailwind for revenue growth.

Revenue from the company's loan servicing arm grew 30% y/y to $9.0 million, while loan originations grew 65% y/y to $22.4 million. We focus on these core lending activities because they are Figure's "bread and butter" and provide recurring revenue for the company, even if Figure Exchange's crypto trading results become choppier heading into 2026.

On the profitability front, Figure's adjusted EBITDA grew roughly 5x y/y to $81.3 million, representing a 51.6% margin that improved more than 30 points y/y.

The company has a near-term goal of hitting 60% adjusted EBITDA margins, which it's driving via a greater mix of capital-light, third-party loans as well as efficiencies and automation applied to the company's own overhead. Per CFO Minchung Kgil's remarks on the Q4 earnings call:

Our medium-term goal for adjusted EBITDA margin is to be above 60%, and our progress this quarter can be explained as follows: First, we are growing volume and assets in Figure Connect and democratized Prime that reduce balance sheet usage and improve contribution margins as more volume moves into our capital-light marketplace. Second, we are seeing our contribution margin from partner-branded volume continue to be around 80% as we have built out the core infrastructure that powers Figure Connect and our partner-branded initiatives. And third, we continue to execute on operating leverage across both fixed and variable expense categories, where our volume increased 131% and our operating expenses, excluding share-based compensation, increased 13% over the same period."

Valuation And Key Takeaways

Despite its rapid growth opportunities, we find that Figure also remains attractively valued. For most of last year, Figure traded at unjustifiable multiples of its bottom line; and now, after its stock price sank, we can no longer say the same.

As shown above, Figure takes at roughly 18x forward adjusted EBITDA. An exact peer set for Figure is tough since its business is so unique, but Figure trades in line with a number of adjacent peers. Coinbase (COIN), which is the number-two crypto exchange, trades at similar ~17x adjusted EBITDA levels to Figure after its recent selloff. Another interesting direct competitor in home lending is legacy incumbent Rocket Mortgage (RKT), which recently purchased Mr. Cooper and Redfin to become a one-stop shop consisting of a real estate brokerage, a mortgage originations platform, and a mortgage servicing arm. Against all of these peers, however, none can match Figure's ~2x y/y top-line growth and its incredible margin expansion trends.

Stay long here and use the post-earnings dip as a buying opportunity.

data.title: AMD Is A No-Brainer Once More
data.description:
Back in early December 2025, I reiterated my buy rating on Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. (AMD) for the third consecutive time. The company saw accelerating data center growth and the partnership with OpenAI was a real confidence booster with regards to their chips' competitiveness. Since then, the stock has seen some ups and downs but overall has experienced very modest losses. The company reported their earnings a couple weeks back and today, we'll analyze those results as well as look at some important recent developments to see if the investment thesis has changed for AMD.

Below, it is shown that AMD is seeing strong business activity, especially in their data center segment. The company's AI GPUs are clearly gaining traction in adoption and that's showing up in their financial performance. With long term tailwinds in place and their near term guidance looking quite solid, the major contraction in the valuation presents investors with a huge opportunity to enter or to add to positions. While there are some risks like the memory shortage and CPU supply concerns, I believe AMD has become a no-brainer once more.

Growth Remains Strong

Let's start off with a look at their 2025 Q4 top line results. In the quarter, AMD generated record revenues of $10.3 billion and that represents a growth rate of 34% YoY. You can see above that this represents a slight deceleration from the previous quarter but there is no question that their business as a whole continues to see strong momentum. AMD stated that they saw strong demand in their Data Center and Client and Gaming segments. The company was also able to smash expectations. They beat analyst consensus by a whopping $599.73 million. With their quarterly revenue just above $10 billion, this is a huge statement of outperformance.

Data Center Performance

There's no question that the data center segment remains the point of focus in AMD's earnings. As shown above, they reported revenues of $5.4 billion and that was a 39% increase YoY. This is a sharp speedup of growth from Q3's 22% growth rate and so it seems this all-important business is gaining momentum. Despite worries about stiff competition from other GPU suppliers like Nvidia (NVDA) and ASICs designers like Broadcom (AVGO), AMD seems to be holding its ground nicely. At CES, the company also unveiled their state of the art Instinct MI440X and so it is clear that their innovation is doing the talking.

Before this latest earnings season, there were concerns that the hyperscalers will cut back on CAPEX with the payoff from these investments still being rather obscure. However, these worries were proven to be unfounded just recently. In their latest earnings report earlier this month, Amazon (AMZN) announced that they will spend $200 billion. This comes after Alphabet's (GOOGL) estimate of $175 billion to $185 billion in capital spending for 2026 and so at this point, there really are no signs that the major cloud service providers are letting up on CAPEX. The competition in that space is fierce and for a GPU provider like AMD, the tailwinds are likely to be strong moving forward. In Q4, data center growth accelerated and there is no evidence that momentum will fade any time soon.

International expansion is also top of mind for the company. By now it is no secret that India is becoming an increasingly vibrant center for AI development. About ten days ago, it was announced that AMD and Tata Consultancy Services will broaden their strategic partnership. As Preeti Singh of Seeking Alpha writes, they will

introduce AMD’s “Helios” rack-scale AI architecture in India, stepping up competition with Nvidia in one of the world’s fastest-growing technology markets.

While the U.S. is of course AMD's largest and most important market, the company's strategic decision to look to international markets like India for growth is a smart one in my view. The recent AI summit in the country clearly shows they are becoming an important source of infrastructure demand as well as innovation. As stated, this also helps them to compete with Nvidia globally.

Lastly, AMD made headlines with their massive Meta (META) deal just yesterday (Feb 24th). It was announced that Meta will deploy up to 6 GW of Instinct chips to power their infrastructure and that this agreement is multiyear and multi-generation. Firstly, it is obvious that this is a major financial win for AMD. CFO Jean Hu stated that

We expect this partnership to drive substantial multi-year revenue growth and be accretive to our non-GAAP earnings per share, marking another significant step forward in delivering on our ambitious long-term financial model.

Secondly, this is another major vote of confidence regarding the competitiveness of AMD's GPUs. As stated earlier, there were worries regarding stiff competition from Nvidia and Broadcom. I believe this massive Meta deal shows that AMD's solutions have matured and are now a formidable alternative to the top chips out there right now.

Profitability Is Solid

In Q4, it seems that AMD has controlled costs well. You can see above that their adjusted gross margin expanded by 3 percentage points YoY. This could also be a signal of increased competitiveness in their products and thus better pricing power. Regardless of where this gross margin strength is coming from, investors should obviously be encouraged.

For the control of expenses, things perhaps could have been a little bit better. As a percentage of revenues, operating expenses increased by 1 percentage point YoY. If you go to their income statement, you'll see that marketing, general and administrative expenses growth outpaced the R&D expense increase and so corporate efficiency may be slightly weaker than desired. Still, with the gross margin strength being a major driver, operating margin still saw expansion of 2 percentage points to show that AMD remains a generally well run business.

Lastly, for the bottom line, the company posted an adjusted EPS of $1.53, up 40% YoY. This outpaced the top line growth rate and beat analyst expectations by $0.21 and so there really shouldn't be many complaints regarding their profitability.

Quarterly Outlook

AMD provided guidance for their 2026 Q1. For revenue, they are expecting to see around $9.8 billion at the midpoint. This implies a YoY growth rate of 32%. While that is another modest deceleration of growth from Q4 levels, I would say that this is still enough to show that business activity will remain robust for the company as a whole moving forward. Furthermore, it should be stated that they guided revenue ~$430 million above consensus expectations and so the outlook looks quite good.

For gross margin, they are projecting 55% and that would be an improvement from 54% in the year ago quarter. Therefore, the cost control and pricing power strength we talked about earlier is set to continue. Lastly, for operating expenses, they see around $3.05 billion for Q1. That represents a 38% jump. Since this outpaces the estimated top line growth rate, expect expense control to be mixed relatively speaking.

As a whole, I view the near term outlook quite favorably, but investors should really focus even more on the increasingly strong long term growth story for their data center segment. Note on their earnings call, CEO Lisa Su stated that

We are well positioned to grow Data Center segment revenue by more than 60% annually over the next 3 to 5 years and scale our AI business to tens of billions in annual revenue in 2027.

Valuation Analysis

AMD's forward P/E ratio has more than halved from the late 2025 peak. At a current reading of just 31.87, I believe the stock has reached bargain levels again. In today's article, it was shown that the company as a whole is performing well. In the in-depth look at their data center segment it was shown that growth is accelerating and recent developments are favorable. Hyperscalers are upping their spending, AMD's push into India is well justified, and the Meta deal is of course a big deal. No pun intended. With the near term outlook looking quite solid and long term tailwinds being strong, I view the company's fundamentals as robust and the prospects as being bright.

With that in mind, the forward P/E ratio's rather sharp contraction over the past few months is really a sign of irrational worry and concern. AMD has the numbers, the contracts, and partnerships to show that they have become a force to be reckoned with instead of being a distant competitor to Nvidia and Broadcom. As a result, I view the current valuation as highly opportunistic.

Risks

There are some risks that investors should have in mind. Firstly, by now it is no secret that the tech sector is feeling the effects of a memory chip shortage. Do note that while AMD's data center segment has taken virtually all the spotlight, the company also has a large Client and Gaming business. There are worries that the memory chip shortage could potentially weigh on PC sales and other consumer electronics. For AMD, since they do still have a good amount of exposure to this space, their company-wide financial performance may still be adversely effected even if their data center segment booms.

Another potential risk is CPU shortages for the Chinese market. Earlier this month it was reported that both Intel (INTC) and AMD had to notify Chinese customers that there were shortages and that deliveries had to be pushed back. For AMD specifically, delivery lead times for select products were pushed back 8 to 10 weeks. Obviously, this has the potential to have near term impacts to their business activity in one of the world's largest markets for CPUs.

Final Thoughts

Back in April of last year, I called AMD stock a no-brainer. I believe the company has earned that title back. In today's analysis, it was shown that they are seeing a great deal of momentum in their all-important data center segment. Growth is accelerating and new deals clearly show that they have become a true major GPU supplier instead of being just a challenger on the outside looking in. While the prospects are arguably as bright as ever, the valuation has more than halved since the peak in late 2025 and so the attractiveness of the stock has increased immensely despite the risks highlighted above. As a result, I have decided to upgrade AMD to a strong buy rating.

data.title: SSE: Still Looks Overpriced, With Heavy Capex Plans
data.description:
U.K. electricity company SSE (SSEZY) has been performing well lately, but to be frank, I still do not see the value here.

I last covered the name in my 2021 “sell” piece, SSE: Green Focus Doesn't Bolster The Investment Case. Since then, it has moved up 74%.

My argument at that time was the company’s focus on green energy threatened profitability. I regard that as standing the test of time: Last year’s net profit was £1.3bn, a 45% decline from the equivalent number for 2021. Last year’s reported earnings per share of £1.08, a decline of 51%. The adjusted earnings per share last year showed growth versus 2021, though: you picks your reporting metric and you takes your choice…

Capital Expenditure Is Set to Remain High

In November, the company published a strategic update that, in the company’s words, would "significantly increas(e) the Group's exposure to UK electricity Networks, and driv(e) long-term value creation with attractive regulated asset value and earnings growth."

This comes at a projected cost of £33bn (fully funded) over five years. Around four-fifths of that is to be spent on regulated UK electricity networks and the remainder on “Renewables and system Flexibilty” (SSE loves idiosyncratic use of uppercase letters).

That reflects a pragmatic shift in my view. The green push of some years ago has fallen out of fashion, explaining shifts in capital allocation priorities at firms including BP (BP), and I think SSE is also shifting its approach in this regard, something I see as positive for the investment case.

But what about the expenditure? We have seen at other U.K. utilities such as National Grid (NGG) that heavy network capex costs can lead to a dividend cut. In National Grid’s case, even after a rights issue and dividend cut, the net debt has continued to grow. As I explain below, SSE itself is no stranger to dividend cuts even before this latest spending plan.

Of the £33bn, the firm reckons £21bn will come from operational cash flow. But the other £14bn is set to come from an “increase in adjusted net debt and hybrid capital.” The company didn’t bother defining “hybrid capital” in its release, although in its (long) “alternative performance measures” section in its most recent results, it says “Adjusted Net Debt and Hybrid Capital” equates most closely to the IFRS measure of “Unadjusted net debt.”

Adjusted net debt and hybrid capital as of September 2025 stood at £11.4bn, so another £21bn is a substantial expansion, even over a five-year period.

That strikes me as an unwelcome development for the balance sheet. On the plus side, the company reckons this will be transformative for earnings. It says, “investments made in Networks and selective Renewables and system Flexibility projects are expected to drive a step-up in earnings of around 50% over the plan, with an adjusted Earnings Per Share CAGR of between 7 - 9% delivering 225 - 250 pence in 2029/30”.

That certainly sounds impressive, but, first, I’d like to see it in practice rather than take it as given ahead of time, and, secondly, if earnings are set to grow significantly, why not fund the whole lot from operational cash flows? The answer, I presume, would be that the spend is presented on a five-year timeline, but the operational cashflow benefits should ultimately flow for much longer.

Again, I think there is an element of “prove it” here before getting excited about this prospect. SSE’s capital allocation track record does not necessarily inspire confidence, while examples like National Grid point to the dangers of capex-heavy infrastructural spend adding to net debt and putting strain on dividend funding.

Dividend is Not Compelling

The most recent interim dividend was raised by around 1%: not exciting at all compared to some U.K. utilities.

From 1999 to 2019 – a 20-year run – the company grew its dividend per share annually. It then cut it in 2020 by 18% and then cut it again in 2024, by 38%. That took it back to a level last seen in 2008-09.

From 2023-24 to 2026-27, the company is targeting annual increases of 5-10%, which it says “aligns future dividends with SSE’s ambitious growth profile” (something not obvious from the past decade’s dividend history, in my view).

Last year saw a 7% increase. The interim increase this year was therefore especially weak, but it could be made up for at the full-year level in order to deliver on the target.

Still, the dividend history is not reassuring at all when it comes to SSE’s commitment to the dividend.

The current yield of 2.5% is also underwhelming, not just for a utility stock but more generally given that even after falling due to a high price, the current FTSE 100 yield is 3.1%.

I Still See the Valuation as Too High

Since my sell piece in 2021, a 74% price gain has proven my approach wrong. Still, just as I thought the company was overpriced then, I still do today and maintain a sell rating.

In a trading statement this month, the company said it expects adjusted earnings per share to be £1.44- £1.52. On an adjusted basis, that implies a prospective P/E ratio of around 17. Bear in mind that this is on an adjusted basis. First-half earnings per share (26.4p) were 27% lower than adjusted earnings per share for the period. Using that ratio as a proxy (a crude approach, but helpful to illustrate the point), then the prospective P/E ratio would be more like 23.

That to me looks overpriced.

What about using a cash flow-based valuation metric? The enterprise value is £42bn, based on £31bn of market cap plus this year’s interim point “net debt and hybrid capital” of £11bn (note: as the company says: ”reported net debt excludes equity classified hybrid capital, see Alternative Performance Measures section”). Last year, cash generated from operations was £2.6bn. So the ratio of enterprise value to cash generated from operations is 16. Again, that looks high to me.

Conclusion

SSE is solidly profitable, and its new five-year strategy ought to embed it yet further in an area of the U.K. economy that benefits from long-term demand and visibility of pricing.

However, I also see some disadvantages to its business model, and despite a rising share price, I think the direction of travel on dividends over the past couple of decades shows a business that has become less, not more, able to create shareholder value.

At its current price, I continue to see it as overvalued and therefore unattractive from an investment perspective.

It will be worth monitoring how the current strategic plan starts to feed into the business, not only in terms of profit but also the balance sheet and whether the expected costs remain the same or rise over the course of the five-year plan.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: The Honest Company: Strong Cash Position As Transformation Gains Traction
data.description:
A Quarter with Mixed Developments

The Honest Company (HNST) reported Q4 2025 results on February 25, 2026, highlighting balance sheet strength and early traction in its transformation while setting expectations for 2026. Some developments were clearly positive. Others indicate that progress may materialize at a more gradual pace. I focus my analysis on organic revenue and adjusted EBITDA, as these are the metrics that allow for an apple-to-apple comparison as the company executes on its transformation strategy. Below are the key developments and my assessment for them.

1. Enhanced Cash Levels

This was the highlight of the quarter, as the cash balance expanded from $71 million in Q3 2025 to $90 million in Q4 2025. For a quarter where the company exited multiple channels and categories, this growth in cash levels is quite notable. Moreover, HNST is a debt-free company, and cash accounts for 35% of its market capitalization as of the close on February 25, 2026.

2. The First Share Repurchase Program

Given the company’s strong balance sheet, it announced a share repurchase program of $25 million. During the conference call, management highlighted that they view the company’s valuation as low and that they intend to repurchase shares opportunistically. This is a good development and will likely act as a catalyst for the share price in the near term.

3. Results Were Within Guidance Range

For FY2025, HNST posted a 5.3% increase in organic revenue, which was in the mid-range of its 4% to 6% growth guidance. FY2025 adjusted EBITDA was $21.8 million and was in the bottom half of the guidance range of $21 million to $23 million. Though this does not qualify as a bad outcome, it suggests that growth will take time despite the pivot to better-performing categories.

4. FY2026 Guidance Is Somewhat Underwhelming

The company is guiding for organic revenue growth of 4% to 6% (Figure 1). It is also guiding to adjusted EBITDA margin expansion of 70 to 150 basis points. Given that the company is dropping roughly a fifth of its revenue base to focus on categories with better prospects and profitability, this guidance appears soft. I view the guidance as conservative and likely to be revised upward as the year progresses.

5. Accelerate Beyond Baby

The company is focusing more on households without babies. This entails expanding into personal care products catered to kids and widening the wipes offering to better serve adults. These product extensions represent a natural evolution of the core product line, making it a low hanging fruit.

6. Improved Inventory Management

The company aims to transition from two warehouses to a single location. This optimization project is expected to be operational in 2H2026. Management seems to be very optimistic about this project and the efficiencies that it expects to extract out of it.

7. Diapers Likely to Remain Challenged In 20226

Diapers account for around 30% of HNST sales and have seen significant headwinds in 2025. There is a trend of consumers moving towards lower-priced items due to economic pressures. This is a major problem for HNST, as its diaper offering is positioned as a premium offering. Also, there was an issue with Target (TGT), where the company had to simplify its product offering. The issue with Target is behind us, but the macro headwind remains in play. The category is likely to register flat to negative growth in 2026. This would explain the soft growth in organic sales guidance, as the company’s second largest category remains pressured.

Figure 1: FY2026 Management Guidance

Share Price

The share price of HNST has been on major correction for the past twelve months. The stock has fallen by 58.5% during this period and currently trades very close to its 52-week low. Is the stock ready to switch gears and start climbing upwards? Well, the transformation resulted in a reported net loss of $23.6 million, but that was mostly write-downs that did not impact the company’s fundamentals. As discussed earlier, the company was able to enhance its cash position, as it benefited from a favorable working capital movement as it exited some product categories and channels. The announcement of the first share buyback program is likely to install confidence among investors that bad times are behind us.

Figure 2: HNST Share Price

Valuation

HNST is trading at an EV-to-Sales (Forward) of 0.57x based on the midpoint of management’s sales guidance for FY2026. This is well below the consumer staples sector median of 1.52x. This shows that the stock has a lot of scope to rerate upwards once investors start believing that the transformation is on the right track. Thus, I share the same view as management that the current share price valuation does not reflect the structural improvement that is taking hold.

Risks

Macro headwinds and tariffs are the key risks facing HNST. The weak macro conditions facing consumers were heavily emphasized by management in the Q4 2025 earnings call. Given that HNST products sell at more premium pricing, the company could face slower sales than anticipated. Consumers could downshift to save money, and this leaves the diapers category the most exposed. Tariffs have increased product costs and will remain a headwind until Q2 2026. Also, the company is in the midst of a transformation process, and there are no guarantees that this plan would work.

Final Thoughts

I believe that HNST posted results with more positives than negatives. Importantly, the balance sheet strengthened during a turnaround quarter. The company is guiding for improved adjusted EBITDA margin driven by a more favorable sales mix. The company is competing in categories where it has a strong value proposition and is looking to solidify its position. Given its low valuation, the stock appears positioned for a potential rebound. I maintain my Bbuyrating on the shares.

data.title: Invesco Small Cap Value Fund Q4 2025 Commentary
data.description:
Key takeaways

1 The fund outperformed its benchmark

Stock selection in information technology ('IT') drove outperformance in the fourth quarter. Conversely, stock selection in health care and financials detracted from relative return.

2 We capitalized on market volatility in an effort to find new opportunities

We took advantage of market volatility during the quarter to purchase several new fund holdings across various sectors. We also eliminated several holdings and used the proceeds to fund investments we believe have more upside potential.

3 Longer term, small-cap value stocks appear attractive relative to S&P 500 Index stocks

The price/earnings (P/E) multiple of the Russell 2000 Value Index has been at a historical discount compared to the P/E of the S&P 500 Index. We believe this valuation represents a compelling long-term investment opportunity.

Manager perspective and outlook

  • In managing the fund, we employ an intrinsic value approach to stock selection. It should be noted that the portfolio is not constructed based on a short-term macroeconomic view. Instead, positioning is driven by a bottom-up stock selection process based on our estimate of intrinsic value, which is based on a company's future cash flows.
  • We seek to create wealth by maintaining a long-term investment horizon and by investing in companies that we believe are significantly undervalued on an absolute basis.
  • Given our focus on intrinsic value and our long-term investment horizon, at quarter end, the fund was positioned with greater exposure to economically sensitive stocks compared to its peers.
  • Following the outperformance of large-cap stocks over small-cap stocks in recent years, we see greater long-term upside to intrinsic value in many small-caps compared to large-caps.
  • At quarter end, the difference between the market prices of the fund's holdings and our estimates of their intrinsic value was attractive, in our view.
  • Although there is no assurance that market value will ever reflect our estimate of the fund's intrinsic value, we believe the gap between price and estimated intrinsic value indicated attractive long-term capital appreciation potential.

Top issuers (% of total market value)

Fund Index
Coherent Corp (COHR) 3.78 0.00
Western Alliance Bancorp (WAL) 2.75 0.00
MKS Inc (MKSI) 2.60 0.00
Hudbay Minerals Inc (HBM) 2.23 0.00
Globe Life Inc (GL) 2.22 0.00
Charles River Laboratories International Inc (CRL) 2.20 0.00
NRG Energy Inc (NRG) 2.02 0.00
Expedia Group Inc (EXPE) 2.00 0.00
Webster Financial Corp (WBS) 1.96 0.00
Saia Inc (SAIA) 1.93 0.00
As of 12/31/25. Holdings are subject to change and are not buy/sell recommendations.

Portfolio positioning

Volatility returned during the quarter, particularly in November. This volatility provided an opportunity for us to purchase stocks with what we saw as attractive long-term upside to intrinsic value across a diverse set of industries. At quarter end, the fund had overweights in more economically sensitive stocks than its benchmark and peers.

Notable Additions:

Charles River Laboratories: This leading contract research organization ('CRO') supports the discovery, development and safe manufacture of new drugs, biologics, vaccines and medical devices. It has a diversified portfolio with exposure to high growth therapeutic areas. Slower spending on biotech and pharma research and development has been a headwind to the stock, which gave us an opportunity to invest at what we saw as an attractive discount to our estimate of intrinsic value.

Globus Medical (GMED): This medical technology company specializes in musculoskeletal solutions for spine, orthopedic trauma and joint reconstruction. The company has faced issues with recent acquisitions, supply chain issues and weakness in its robotics segment, which together provided an opportunity to purchase the stock at what we saw as an attractive discount to our estimate of intrinsic value.

ArcBest (ARCB): This logistics and freight transportation company operates less-than-truckload ('LTL') shipping, which is used for shipments too large for parcel delivery but too small for a full truckload. The trucking industry has been in a multi-year cyclical downturn; however, we believe ArcBest's operational efficiency and technological advancements using artificial intelligence ('AI') should position the company well once demand recovers.

Notable Sales:

Chart Industries (GTLS): A global leader in cryogenic and gas-handling technologies, the company provides highly engineered equipment to support a wide range of industries, with a focus on clean energy and industrial gas solutions. The company is being acquired by Baker Hughes (BKR) (not a fund holding) in an all-cash transaction expected to close in mid-2026. We opted to sell the stock to fund other opportunities we believe have better upside to intrinsic value.

Mastec (MTZ): An infrastructure contractor, delivering critical services across communications, energy, power and water systems, Mastec is involved with the AI infrastructure build-out for fiber networks and data centers. The stock rose in the fourth quarter, which gave us an opportunity to sell the position to fund opportunities we believe have more upside to intrinsic value.

Performance highlights

Stock selection in the IT sector was the largest contributor to relative performance. Stock selection and an overweight in materials also aided relative return. Stock selection in health care and financials detracted the most from relative return. Overall, performance drivers were largely stock specific.

Contributors to performance

Lumentum: Shares of this market-leading designer and manufacturer of innovative optical and photonic products rallied in the fourth quarter, fueled by apparent investor enthusiasm for its AI-driven growth potential.

Globus Medical: The orthopedic device maker reported better-than-expected financial results with strong organic growth and an increase in its forward earnings guidance. The company's recent acquisitions are expected to provide synergies that we believe should boost earnings in 2026.

Coherent: This laser company develops and manufactures optoelectronic components and devices. Its optical transceivers are key enablers for networking of AI servers. Shares rose due to surging AI data center demand, strong growth of networking revenue and expanding profit margins supported by a more focused, high-return product portfolio.

Detractors from performance

AECOM: AECOM is a global infrastructure consulting and engineering firm that provides planning, design, construction and management for transportation, water, environmental, energy and building projects worldwide. The company reported better-than-expected earnings, but revenues were below expectations, driving the stock lower.

Crane NXT: This industrial technology company provides technological solutions to secure, detect and authenticate physical and digital assets. Shares declined amid reignited trade tensions with China. Though the company reported better-than-expected earnings and revenue growth, management reduced its earnings outlook for the full year, which also sent shares lower.

PENN Entertainment: The company operates physical casinos in the US, along with a growing digital gaming and sports-betting platform. Shares declined after third quarter earnings missed expectations. The company's announcement ending its partnership with ESPN also seemed to dampen investor sentiment.

data.title: Nasdaq And U.S. Index Outlook: Stock Markets Tumble; The Great Tech Fake Out
data.description:
By Elior Manier

What a fakeout in the stock markets. It hasn't been easy to find any clarity in recent price action, and today marks yet another sign of why. Nvidia (NVDA) just posted immense earnings, beating all records by a wide margin, with $68.13 billion in revenue for Q4, a +70% y/y increase in earnings.

Despite also exceeding expectations, the AI chip designer is tumbling in today's session, down 4.00% and even extended below 5% at its trough. (A bounce from its 50-Day MA is currently ongoing – keep a close eye on such flows). Check out this post to learn more.

I warned of some short-covering ahead of the earnings yesterday, but that is a precise execution of the adage "Buy the rumors, sell the news." The drop is also dragging other semiconductor equities, with Broadcom (AVGO) (-6.50%), Micron (MU) (-4.70%), and AMD (AMD) (-3.70%) bleeding, and the rest of the sector bleeding.

Markets are bouncing timidly from the session lows, with the Nasdaq retesting 25,000, down close to 1.50%, while the Dow Jones remains unchanged.

A proof of the recent turn in narrative: AI is priced to be a disruptor for markets. The revolution is inevitable, and while current demand is set to exceed all expectations, anxiety about its impact on existing businesses is turning into fear.

What if a reassignment of funds from the tech sector triggered a cascade of bankruptcies in a heavily leveraged industry? The doom scenario is still quite far off, and U.S. indexes are still less than 10% from their all-time highs.

The final round of US-Iran talks is also just restarting. Expect to receive some news promptly. Let's look at the technical situation by diving into today’s session charts and key trading levels for the major US indices: the Dow Jones, Nasdaq, and S&P 500.

Current Session's Stock Heatmap

The drop in semiconductors really spread to the entire market as October flows look to be picking up again. Check out throughout the session to see if this spreads to a wider market correction; for now, we'll check out intraday charts to get some clues.

Dow Jones 1H Chart and Trading Levels

The Dow is now turning lower after a volatile open, failing to retest 50,000. Immediate support comes at the 200-hour MA, but looking at the strength of the selloff (and oil picking up), it could be difficult to spot a rebound here.

If prices extend below 49,350, expect a cascade of profit-taking and a fall back towards 48,000 towards the month-end (especially if US-Iran talks fail).

Dow Jones technical levels for trading:

Resistance Levels

  • Morning highs: 49,850
  • January ATH resistance 49,500 to 49,700 (rejection)
  • 49,900 to 50,000 resistance (range highs)
  • Index all-time highs: 50,512

Support Levels

  • Key 1H MA 49,390 – bearish below!
  • Major pivot – 49,000 to 49,200
  • Past week support 48,640 to 48,750 (past week test)
  • November ATH 48,300 to 48,500 minor support
  • Key support from 47,500 to 48,000 (next main support)
  • 45,000 psychological level (main support on higher timeframe)

Nasdaq 1H Chart and Trading Levels

Nasdaq sent dark signs in this morning's action, rejecting the 25,500 resistance and now looking to retest its 200-hour MA after a faint rebound (24,881). Any hourly close below would confirm the profit-taking, which could extend back towards 24,000 for month-end (tomorrow).

Nasdaq technical levels of interest:

Resistance Levels

  • 25,400 to 25,500 kKey intraday resistance
  • 25,000 pivot level
  • All-time high resistance zone 26,100 to 26,300

Support Levels

  • 24,881 200-hour MA immediate support and morning lows
  • 24,500 to 25,600 key support (range support)
  • February support: 24,150 to 24,200
  • October-November support: 23,800 to 24,000
  • Early 2025 ATH at 22,000 to 22,229 support

S&P 500 1H Chart and Trading Levels

The S&P 500 formed its own double-top in this morning's action. Watch how traders react to oversold levels being reached on shorter timeframes. Crossing below its 200-hour MA (6,873) will also act as a sign of further selling to expect in stock markets. Look around 6,750 for month-end if the mood really turns sour.

S&P 500 technical levels of interest:

Resistance Levels

  • Previous ATH resistance 6,945 to 6,975 (testing)
  • Current ATH 7,020
  • All-time high resistance: 7,000 to 7,020 (range highs)

Support Levels

  • Key pivot zone 6,880 to 6,900
  • Current range intraday support 6,820
  • Mini support 6,830 to 6,850
  • 6,800 psychological support
  • February lows: 6,730 (higher timeframe range lows)
  • 6,400 major psychological support

Safe trades, and keep a close eye on the US-Iran developments!

data.title: Janus Henderson Developed World Bond Fund Q4 2025 Commentary
data.description:
At a glance

Performance

The Fund returned 1.04% and the Bloomberg Global Aggregate Credit Index returned 0.94%.

Contributors/detractors

The main positive contributor to relative performance was the overweight position to corporate bonds and bank loans. Yield curve positioning detracted.

Outlook

We maintain a constructive outlook for the global economy heading into 2026, as signs point to a soft-landing scenario.

Investment environment

  • Divergence in sovereign bond performance and developed world monetary policy defined the fourth quarter. UK Gilts and U.S. Treasuries outperformed, while yields rose (prices fell) in Europe and Japan. U.S. Treasuries bull-steepened, with front-end rates falling over the quarter.
  • The Federal Reserve (Fed) cut interest rates twice over the quarter by a combined 50 basis points ('bps') to 3.75% in response to a weaker jobs market, with the U.S. unemployment rate hitting a four-year high of 4.6% in November.
  • Other data releases were more positive, with U.S. inflation dipping below expectations in November and third-quarter (gross domestic product) GDP growth that surprised on the upside. Despite policymakers indicating, in aggregate, that they anticipate one more cut in 2026, futures markets are pricing in an additional two cuts next year.
  • In the UK, the Bank of England (BOE) lowered its policy rate by 25 bps in a split 5-4 vote, with policymakers citing subdued growth and easing inflation pressures. The UK's Consumer Price Index ('CPI') eased to 3.2% in November, from 3.6% in October, below the 3.5% forecast and marking the lowest level since March. The Autumn Budget revealed a surprise £22 billion of fiscal headroom (versus the expected £9 billion), achieved through front-loaded spending and upbeat revenue forecasts ahead of the 2026 general election.
  • December brought another wave of bond selling across Europe, fueled by rising expectations of a European Central Bank ('ECB') rate increase in 2026. The shift in sentiment followed Isabel Schnabel's remarks in a Bloomberg interview, where she said she was "rather comfortable" with the idea that the next policy move could be a hike. The Governing Council subsequently nudged its 2026 growth and inflation forecasts higher. In France, political uncertainty lingered as the government failed to pass a full state budget, relying instead on a stopgap measure to avoid a shutdown.
  • Another key development in the quarter came from Japan, where Sanae Takaichi won the Liberal Democratic Party ('LDP') leadership race in October and was appointed prime minister later that month. Her victory took markets by surprise. In addition, the government unveiled a substantial fiscal stimulus package in November.
  • The Bank of Japan (BoJ) raised its policy rate by 25 bps, to 0.75%, the highest level in 30 years, while signaling openness to further hikes. The 10-year Japanese Government Bond ('JGB') yield climbed above 2.0% following the BoJ decision, reaching its highest level since 1999.
  • In credit markets, October was a big month of issuance in U.S. investment-grade bonds, which saw record October supply of $158 billion. Meta Platforms (META) priced $30 billion of debt. This was followed by another major supply event from Google (GOOGL) in early November. Bond issuance to fund the artificial intelligence ('AI') capital expenditure (CAPEX) of hyperscalers is now a dominant theme.
  • Public credit markets remained supported by formidably strong investor demand, driven by high all-in yields and low default rates. However, the credit market continued to be selective. CCC rated corporate bonds in the U.S. and Europe underperformed over the quarter. Investors are showing caution and avoiding capital structures that are most at risk of restructuring.

Portfolio review

The main positive contributor to fund performance was the overweight position to corporate bonds and bank loans, which benefited from income and spread compression.

On the credit side, we actively participated in several new issues in the U.S., Europe, and the UK, while switching out of bonds that had performed strongly, which in our view had become highly valued relative to their fundamentals, to generate liquidity. We bought bonds of from AA rated tech issuers such as Google, well-capitalized banks, and insurers where spreads were appealing. These were new or increased positions in subordinated debt of these institutions, at yields in the 5.5% to 7% range. We continue to find the backdrop more conducive to taking credit risk rather than duration risk.

In addition to the credit holdings, we retain a long position in high-yield credit derivatives ('CDX'), which was accretive for the yield of the portfolio. Our yield curve positioning detracted during the quarter.

Manager outlook

We maintain a constructive outlook for the global economy heading into 2026. Signs point to a soft-landing scenario: inflation has cooled considerably without a recession, and underlying growth remains resilient across major regions. The U.S. economy demonstrated positive momentum – third-quarter GDP surprised to the upside at 4.3%. Europe's growth outlook has improved from mid-year doldrums; lower energy costs and a weaker euro should spur some pick-up, albeit growth likely will be moderate (approximately 1% in 2026). China's stimulus measures into 2026 may also stabilize global demand.

Definitions

A yield curve plots the yields (interest rate) of bonds with equal credit quality but differing maturity dates. Typically bonds with longer maturities have higher yields.

Monetary Policy refers to the policies of a central bank, aimed at influencing the level of inflation and growth in an economy. It includes controlling interest rates and the supply of money.

Credit Spread is the difference in yield between securities with similar maturity but different credit quality. Widening spreads generally indicate deteriorating creditworthiness of corporate borrowers, and narrowing indicate improving.

Basis point (BP) equals 1/100 of a percentage point. 1 bp = 0.01%, 100 bps = 1%.

Consumer Price Index ('CPI') is an unmanaged index representing the rate of inflation of the U.S. consumer prices as determined by the U.S. Department of Labor Statistics.

Performance attribution is a method used to analyze and quantify the performance of an investment portfolio relative to its benchmark and does not represent actual performance. Attribution is calculated using gross returns before the deduction of advisory fees and considers differences in weighting for the portfolio and the index. This analysis aims to break down the portfolio's performance into different components to understand what factors contributed to relative return, among other performance characteristics. The analysis can provide insights into which decisions positively or negatively impacted the portfolio's performance and serves as the basis for this discussion.

There is no assurance the stated objective(s) will be met.

Investing involves risk, including the possible loss of principal and fluctuation of value.

Foreign securities are subject to additional risks including currency fluctuations, political and economic uncertainty, increased volatility, lower liquidity and differing financial and information reporting standards, all of which are magnified in emerging markets.

Fixed income securities are subject to interest rate, inflation, credit and default risk. The bond market is volatile. As interest rates rise, bond prices usually fall, and vice versa. The return of principal is not guaranteed, and prices may decline if an issuer fails to make timely payments or its credit strength weakens.

Mortgage-backed securities ('MBS') may be more sensitive to interest rate changes. They are subject to extension risk, where borrowers extend the duration of their mortgages as interest rates rise, and prepayment risk, where borrowers pay off their mortgages earlier as interest rates fall. These risks may reduce returns.

High-yield or "junk" bonds involve a greater risk of default and price volatility and can experience sudden and sharp price swings.

Derivatives can be more volatile and sensitive to economic or market changes than other investments, which could result in losses exceeding the original investment and magnified by leverage.

Industry and Sector Risk. Investing a significant portion of its assets in companies in the same industry or economic sector can make the Fund more vulnerable to unfavorable developments than funds that invest more broadly. A more concentrated portfolio can be susceptible to factors affecting that group and may be more volatile than less concentrated investments or the market as a whole.

ESG Investment Risk: Because it considers environmental, social, and governance ("ESG") factors in selecting securities, the Fund may perform differently from funds that do not. ESG considerations and exclusionary criteria may limit investments in certain industries or sectors, and the Fund's performance might vary from similar funds that do not formally consider ESG factors. Information from issuers and third parties on ESG considerations, which management may use, is evolving and may be incomplete, inaccurate, or inconsistently applied across issuers and industries. The risk that the Fund may be required to sell securities when it might be otherwise disadvantageous to do so is heightened when ESG considerations and exclusionary criteria are applied.

ESG Integration: As part of its investment process, portfolio management evaluates ESG risks and opportunities ("ESG Factors") deemed financially material, alongside other investment factors. ESG Factors are among many considerations in investment decisions and may not solely determine portfolio inclusion or exclusion.

Bloomberg Global Aggregate Credit Index measures the credit sector of the global investment grade fixed-rate bond market, including corporate, government and agency securities. Index performance does not reflect the expenses of managing a portfolio as an index is unmanaged and not available for direct investment.

data.title: Fidelity Low-Priced Stock Fund Q4 2025 Commentary
data.description:
Performance Review

For the fourth quarter, the fund's Retail Class shares gained 1.64%, lagging the 2.19% advance of the benchmark, the Russell 2000® Index. We'll note that longer-term performance comparisons favor the fund over the benchmark.

U.S. small-cap stocks posted a gain in the fourth quarter, according to the benchmark, extending a rebound that began in early April, but at a slower pace. The advance was supported by strong corporate fundamentals, a resilient economy, an ongoing boom in spending on artificial intelligence and the Federal Reserve's first interest-rate reductions since December 2024. Within the Russell 2000® Index, small-cap value stocks (+3.26%) modestly outpaced small-cap growth (+1.22%) in Q4. Large-caps, as represented by the Russell Top 200 Index (+2.99%), had a slight advantage over small-caps in Q4.

Only three of 11 sectors outpaced the small-cap-oriented Russell 2000® Index. Health care (+19%) had the strongest outcome and particularly shined in November. Materials (+5%) also posted a solid gain, while the growth-oriented communication services sector rose about 4%, benefiting from the transformative potential of generative AI. Conversely, the defensive-oriented consumer staples sector (-5%) lagged, as did information technology (-5%) consumer discretionary (-4%) and industrials (-2%).

Industry positioning detracted from the fund's performance versus the benchmark, especially in health care. A non-benchmark position in industrial technology company Crane NXT (CXT) (-30%) was the largest individual relative detractor. Shares of Crane NXT hit an all-time high in October. However, as the Trump administration threatened to levy steep trade tariffs on Chinese imports, reigniting fears of a trade war, shares of Crane NXT slid downward through year end. Aggressive U.S. trade policies threatened many companies exposed to the industrials sector, as costs become unpredictable and can disrupt manufacturing operations.

In contrast, a non-benchmark stake in micro-chip manufacturer Micron Technology (MU) (+72%) was the top individual relative contributor. Shares of the company have soared since hitting a low on April 4, 2025. The company is only one of three that specialize in high-bandwidth memory, which is increasingly in demand as technology driven by artificial intelligence becomes more prevalent. During the past year, Micron Technology's revenue, as well as its cash flow, have dramatically increased due in large part to brisk demand for its chips. As Micron Technology's stock approached our target valuation this quarter, we trimmed the fund's position to invest in other investment opportunities.

Portfolio Positioning and Market Outlook

The fund's positioning among sectors remained largely unchanged the past three months, as we made only modest shifts based on where we found the best potential risk-adjusted returns and opportunistic ideas that fit our investment philosophy. Our investment process centers on being patient, taking a long-term view and comparing price to value with the hope of choosing undiscovered gems. When we evaluate a stock, we typically think about owning it for three to five years, looking past short-term noise and focusing on key fundamental drivers over a multiyear period.

As 2026 begins, we continue to find many investments outside the U.S. to be attractive, given the valuation gap that exists following an extended period of significant U.S. equity outperformance. That said, in the U.S., we are finding some interesting opportunities in areas where prices have been dislocated due to revised tariffs and tariff policy uncertainty. We are focusing on companies that we believe will successfully adapt to a "new normal," and where the market is pricing in a much more pessimistic outlook. In addition to identifying companies that don't trade at an excessive valuation, we seek those that consistently generate positive cash flow. When the market is narrow and favors only a few winners, we believe it helps us find compelling ideas that are overlooked, and thus provides opportunity for investment.

References

  1. Life of Fund ('LOF') if performance is less than 10 years. Fund inception date: 12/27/1989.
  2. This expense ratio is from the most recent prospectus and generally is based on amounts incurred during the most recent fiscal year, or estimated amounts for the current fiscal year in the case of a newly launched fund. It does not include any fee waivers or reimbursements, which would be reflected in the fund's net expense ratio.

Fidelity® Low-Priced Stock Fund (FLPSX)

Investment Approach

Fidelity® Low-Priced Stock Fund uses an opportunistic approach in seeking undervalued stocks. It focuses mostly on small- and mid-cap companies, including overseas. Most holdings have share prices below $35 per share or an earnings yield at or above the median for the Russell 2000® Index. (The earnings yield is the inverse of the price-earnings (P/E) ratio; a high earnings yield means a low P/E ratio.)

Our investment process is based on the belief that many low-priced stocks are mispriced. Mispricings are especially likely to occur in businesses that seem boring and out of favor or which require careful analysis.

We seek to buy higher-quality companies with stable growth prospects that trade at a discount to our estimate of intrinsic (fair) value.

Where the gap between price and value is especially compelling, we may invest in firms whose near-term prospects appear challenged. We cast a wide net, and many holdings are outside of the fund's benchmark.

We invest with a long-term time horizon and global perspective, seeking to deliver attractive risk-adjusted returns. To help manage risk, we look for understandable businesses that are resilient and growing, with honest and capable management, purchased at a modest price.

Relative Weights

Relative weights represents the % of fund assets in a particular market segment, asset class or credit quality relative to the benchmark. A positive number represents an overweight, and a negative number is an underweight. The fund's benchmark is listed immediately under the fund name in the Performance Summary.

3-Year Risk/return Statistics

Beta is a measure of the volatility of a fund relative to its benchmark index. A beta greater (leSs) than 1 is more (leSs) volatile than the index.

Information Ratio measures a fund's active return (fund's average monthly return minus the benchmark's average monthly return) in relation to the volatility of its active returns.

R-Squared measures how a fund's performance correlates with a benchmark index's performance and shows what portion of it can be explained by the performance of the overall market/index. R-Squared ranges from 0, meaning no correlation, to 1, meaning perfect correlation. An R-Squared value of less than 0.5 indicates that annualized alpha and beta are not reliable performance statistics.

Sharpe Ratio is a measure of historical risk-adjusted performance. It is calculated by dividing the fund's excess returns (the fund's average annual return for the period minus the 3-month "risk free" return rate) and dividing it by the standard deviation of the fund's returns. The higher the ratio, the better the fund's return per unit of risk. The three month "risk free" rate used is the 90-day Treasury Bill rate.

Standard Deviation is a statistical measurement of the dispersion of a fund's return over a specified time period. Fidelity calculates standard deviations by comparing a fund's monthly returns to its average monthly return over a 36-month period, and then annualizes the number. Investors may examine historical standard deviation in conjunction with historical returns to decide whether a fund's volatility would have been acceptable given the returns it would have produced. A higher standard deviation indicates a wider dispersion of past returns and thus greater historical volatility. Standard deviation does not indicate how the fund actually performed, but merely indicates the volatility of its returns over time.

Tracking Error is the divergence between the price behavior of a position or a portfolio and the price behavior of a benchmark, creating an unexpected profit or loss.

data.title: Tracking George Soros's 13F Portfolio - Q4 2025 Update
data.description:
This article is part of a series that provides an ongoing analysis of the changes made to George Soros's 13F stock portfolio on a quarterly basis. It is based on George Soros's regulatory 13F Form filed on 02/13/2026. Please visit our Tracking Soros Fund Management Holdings article for an idea on his investment philosophy and our previous update for the fund's moves during Q3 2025.

Soros Fund Management invests globally and the long positions in the US market reported in the 13F filings represent ~25% of the overall portfolio. The 13F portfolio value increased from $7.02B to $8.63B this quarter. The number of positions increased from 184 to 244. Very small stock positions, short and long positions in index ETFs, and large debt holdings together account for well over 50% of the 13F holdings. The investments are diversified with a large number of very small equity positions, a small number of large equity positions, and a few large debt holdings. The focus of this article is on the larger equity positions. The top three individual stocks held as of Q4 2025 were Amazon, Alphabet, Salesforce. To learn about Soros' distinct trading style and philosophy, check out his classic book "The Alchemy of Finance" and other works.

New Stakes:

CoreWeave (CRWV) Puts: The 1.43% CRWV Short Position through Puts was established this quarter as the stock traded between ~$64 and ~$153. It is now at $97.63.

New Gold Inc. (NGD): The ~1% NGD position was established this quarter at prices between $6.01 and $9.59. The stock currently trades well above that range at $13.14.

Amicus Therapeutics (FOLD), Clearwater Analytics (CWAN), Dayforce Inc. (DAY), Medline Inc. (MDLN), Hologic Inc. (HOLX), Cidara Therapeutics (CDTX), Avidity Biosciences (RNAM), Huntsman Corp (HUN) & Calls, ITT Inc. (ITT), Janus Henderson Group (JHG), Hillenbrand Inc. (HI), and Synovus Financial (SNV): These are small new positions purchased during the quarter.

Stake Disposals:

Aramark (ARMK): ARMK was a 1.24% of the portfolio position established during Q2 2025 at prices between ~$30 and ~$42. There was a ~45% stake increase during the last quarter at prices between ~$37 and ~$44.50. The disposal this quarter was at prices between ~$35 and ~$41. The stock currently trades at $41.84.

Stake Increases:

Amazon.com (AMZN): AMZN is the top 13F position at 7.11% of the portfolio. Recent activity follows. The stake saw a ~30% increase during Q1 2025 at prices between ~$180 and ~$233. There was a ~12% trimming during the next quarter at prices between ~$161 and ~$224. The last quarter saw the position built to the largest 13F stake at prices between ~$211 and ~$239. This quarter also saw a ~12% stake increase at prices between ~$211 and ~$259. The stock currently trades at ~$208.

Salesforce Inc. (CRM): The 1.59% CRM stake was established during Q3 2024 at prices between ~$238 and ~$277. The next quarter saw a ~90% stake increase at prices between ~$271 and ~$368. That was followed by a ~50% stake increase during Q1 2025 at prices between ~$270 and ~$369. The next quarter saw a ~12% trimming at prices between ~$230 and ~$296. There was a ~20% stake increase during the last quarter at prices between ~$227 and ~$277. That was followed by a ~12% further increase this quarter at prices between ~$222 and ~$269. The stock currently trades well below their purchase price ranges at ~$200.

TKO Group Holdings (TKO): The 1.54% TKO stake was established during Q1 2025 at prices between ~$114 and ~$149. The last quarter saw a ~85% stake increase at prices between ~$152 and ~$213. The stock is now above those ranges at ~$224. There was a minor ~3% stake increase this quarter.

Microsoft (MSFT) & Calls: The 1.47% MSFT stake was purchased during Q2 2025 at prices between ~$345 and ~$501. There was a ~45% reduction during the last quarter at prices between ~$489 and ~$556. There was a ~160% stake increase this quarter at prices between ~$465 and ~$554. The stock is now at ~$402.

NVIDIA (NVDA): NVIDIA is a 1.44% of the portfolio position. Recent activity follows. The stake saw a ~40% increase during the last quarter at prices between ~$152 and ~$187. There was a ~22% further increase this quarter at prices between ~$170 and ~$212. The stock currently trades at ~$185.

Apple Inc. (AAPL): A short position through AAPL Puts was established during Q1 2025 as AAPL traded between ~$220 and ~$260. The next quarter saw the position sold down by ~85% as AAPL traded between ~$169 and ~$225. The last quarter saw an about turn: The Puts were closed and a new 1.27% long stake was established at prices between ~$202 and ~$258. There was a ~20% stake increase this quarter at prices between ~$244 and ~$289. The stock currently trades at ~$273.

Taiwan Semi (TSM): The TSM stake saw a ~155% increase this quarter at prices between ~$267 and ~$314. The stock currently trades well above that range at ~$377 and the stake is now at 1.23% of the portfolio.

Confluent Inc. (CFLT) & Calls: CFLT stake saw a ~90% increase this quarter at prices between $19.54 and $30.33. The stock is now at $30.63.

Walt Disney (DIS): The ~1% DIS stake was established during the last quarter at prices between ~$112 and ~$125. There was a ~20% stake increase this quarter at prices between ~$102 and ~$117. The stock is now at ~$106.

CMS Energy (CMS): The 0.90% CMS stake was established during the last quarter at prices between ~$69 and ~$75. There was a ~43% stake increase this quarter at prices between ~$69 and ~$76. It is now at $77.05.

Ally Financial (ALLY): The 0.89% ALLY position saw a ~130% stake increase this quarter at prices between ~$37 and ~$47. The stock currently trades at $41.94.

Corebridge Financial (CRBG): CRBG is a 0.72% of the portfolio position. Recent activity follows. Q2 2025 saw a ~25% stake increase at prices between ~$24 and ~$36. That was followed by a ~20% further increase during the last quarter at prices between ~$31 and ~$36.50. The stock currently trades at $27.89. There was a minor ~3% further increase this quarter.

Air Lease (AL), Atlassian (TEAM), CyberArk Software (CYBR), Chart Industries (GTLS), IDACORP (IDA), and Pony AI (PONY): These stakes were increased during the quarter.

Stake Decreases:

Alphabet Inc. (GOOGL): GOOGL is now a 2.32% of the portfolio position. It was purchased during Q2 2019 at prices between ~$52 and ~$64 and reduced by ~50% in Q1 2020 at prices between ~$53 and ~$76. The stake has wavered. Recent activity follows. Q1 2025 saw the position sold down by ~63% at prices between ~$161 and ~$203. The stake was almost sold out during the next quarter at prices between ~$143 and ~$183. The last quarter saw the position rebuilt at prices between ~$173 and ~$256. The stock is now at ~$307. There was a minor ~3% trimming this quarter.

Note: Alphabet is a frequently traded stock in Soros' portfolio.

Smurfit Westrock (SW): SW is currently at ~1% of the portfolio. It was established during Q1 2024. Q3 2024 saw the initial position doubled at prices between ~$38 and ~$50. Q2 2025 saw a ~9% further increase at prices between ~$37 and ~$47. The position was sold down by ~70% this quarter at prices between ~$33 and ~$44. The stock currently trades at $46.47.

Figure Technology (FIGR): FIGR is a ~1% of the portfolio position purchased during the last quarter at prices between ~$30 and ~$46 and the stock currently trades at $34.04. There was a minor ~6% trimming this quarter.

Note: FIGR had an IPO in September priced at $25 per share. Trading started at $36 and closed that day at ~$31.

Sunrun Inc. (RUN): The RUN stake is now at 0.90% of the portfolio. Recent activity follows. The last quarter saw a ~40% reduction at prices between ~$8 and ~$18. That was followed by a ~35% selling this quarter at prices between ~$16 and ~$22.50. The stock currently trades at $20.42.

Interactive Brokers (IBKR): IBKR is now a 0.57% of the portfolio position. The original stake was built during Q2 2025 at prices between ~$33 and ~$56. There was a ~30% reduction in the last quarter at prices between ~$53 and ~$70. This quarter saw a ~50% selling at prices between ~$59 and ~$73. The stock currently trades at $74.56.

Flutter Entertainment (FLUT): FLUT is now a very small 0.23% position. A large stake was built during Q1 2025 at prices between ~$218 and ~$285. There was a ~16% reduction during the next quarter at prices between ~$197 and ~$286. This quarter saw the position sold down by ~80% at prices between ~$189 and ~$261. It is now at ~$123.

Datadog (DDOG), GFL Environmental (GFL), Snowflake (SNOW), and Somnigroup International (SGI): These stakes were reduced this quarter.

Kept Steady:

data.title: John Hancock Balanced Fund Q4 2025 Commentary
data.description:
Highlights

  • In the fourth quarter, market participants experienced solid economic growth, stable credit conditions, and a modest increase in inflation.
  • The fund's equities outperformed due to favorable security selection, particularly in communication services; however, stock picking in consumer staples and real estate modestly detracted.
  • The fund's fixed-income securities outperformed, reflecting an underweight in U.S. Treasuries and an overweight in mortgage-backed securities; conversely, overweights in high-yield bonds and asset-backed securities detracted.

Market review and outlook

In Q4, market participants experienced solid economic growth, stable credit conditions, and only a modest increase in inflation. The U.S. Federal Reserve (Fed) enacted two quarter-point interest rate cuts, bringing the total reduction for the year to three-quarters of a percentage point.

Meanwhile, corporate earnings again outpaced market expectations. Although volatility was limited for the market, individual stocks saw significant divergence in performance, creating what we saw as a very favorable environment for security selection.

We expect Q4 earnings to remain strong, especially given robust holiday spending, while equity valuations appear elevated. We also anticipate increased volatility in the coming year, particularly in light of ongoing geopolitical uncertainty, the upcoming U.S. midterm elections, and divergent central bank policies.

We expect the Fed to maintain a cautious approach, and for fixed-income volatility to increase as investors navigate uncertainty regarding the future path of Fed policy. Although short-term yields declined in 2025, we believe that elevated longer-term yields could provide an attractive investment. In addition, credit fundamentals remain stable.

Contributors and detractors

The fund's equity portfolio outperformed due to strong security selection, particularly in the communication services sector. Stock picking and sector allocation—the latter of which derived from the fund's bottom-up security selection process—in healthcare also contributed. Security selection in consumer staples and real estate modestly detracted.

Individually, Eli Lilly & Company (LLY) contributed to relative performance. Shares of the pharmaceutical company rose amid continued growth in its GLP-1 drug franchise. Also contributing was Freeport-McMoRan, Inc. (FCX), a mining company that benefited from rising copper and gold prices. Alphabet, Inc. (GOOGL) further lifted the fund's relative performance.

In contrast, Zebra Technologies Corp. (ZBRA) detracted. The developer of bar-code technologies produced solid quarterly earnings that nevertheless appeared to lag investor expectations. Also hampering the fund's result was BellRing Brands, Inc. (BRBR), a maker of protein shakes. In Q4, its stock fell amid broadening concerns about heightened competition. Further detracting was the fund's lack of exposure to Apple, Inc. (AAPL), a large benchmark component that modestly outperformed the market.

For the fixed-income portfolio, which outperformed, the main contributors were an underweight in U.S. Treasuries and an overweight in mortgage-backed securities. However, overweights in high-yield bonds and asset-backed securities detracted from performance.

Portfolio changes

The fund's equity and fixed-income allocations finished 2025 at about 58% and 42%, respectively, little changed from September 30. Within the quarter, however, the fund's stock allocation rose with the market's outperformance, leading us to reduce the portfolio's equity allocation to maintain our desired underweight.

We established 7 new equity positions and sold 3 stocks from the fund. Turnover moderated but remained higher than usual, reflecting our active repositioning to take advantage of stock-level opportunities created by market volatility.

In the fixed-income portfolio, we added to the fund's securitized credit, primarily through purchases of non-agency residential MBS and non-traditional subsectors of the ABS market. In contrast, we reduced the fund's allocations to investment-grade and high-yield corporate bonds.
